snippet: With a sensor and a compass attached to their brains, rats without sight learn to navigate a maze as well as rats that see.
abstract: Study in journal Current Biology concludes that blind rats with geomagnetic sensors and compasses attached to their brains are able to navigate maze as well as sighted rats, demonstrating ability to use allocentric sense, or awareness of one’s body relative to its environment, to replace vision; findings may prove useful in helping blind people.
lead_paragraph: With a sensor and a compass attached to their brains, rats without sight learn to navigate a maze as well as rats that see.

headline.print_headline: Vision: A Possible Electronic Guide for the Blind
headline.main: A Navigation System for Rats Nearly as Good as Sight
